citations.narrative:
The licensee is not maintaining some areas in the outdoor housing facilities in good repair to protect the animals from
injury and to contain the animals:
In the alpaca pasture, a piece of woven wire from where an old enclosure used to be located was stuck in the ground and
sticking up in an area where the alpacas could step on it. Woven wire sticking up could cause injury to the alpacas.
Ensure to remove this wire and maintain the alpaca pasture in good repair to protect the animals from injury.
***Correct by 6/9/2025.
In the bison enclosure, a loop of wire is loose at the base of the fence near the area where the licensee feeds grain. There
is also a gap below the fence in that area. The loop of wire could cause injury to the bison, and the gap below the fence
could allow the public to contact the bison, resulting in injury to the animal or public. Ensure to maintain the bison's fence
in good repair to protect and contain him.
***Correct by 6/9/2025.
The inspectors observed a small goat kid going under the primary enclosure fence where there was a gap and then going
back in with the herd later. The primary enclosure fence does not contain all of the animals. If goats are not contained
within their enclosure, they could get injured. Ensure that the fence is maintained in a manner that safely contains and
protects the goats, including the small goat kids.
***Correct by 6/17/2025.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Presence of wild rats observed during inspection indicates the licensee’s program for control of mammalian pests is not
effective. During the inspection, inspectors observed at least two rats going into the silver pheasant's enclosure and
eating grain near the pheasant. Rats can carry and spread diseases that could harm the animals. Ensure that a safe and
effective program to control rodent pests such as rats is established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-
being of the birds and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas.
***Correct by 6/20/2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative and the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The licensee is not maintaining some areas in the outdoor housing facilities in good repair to protect the animals from 
injury and to contain the animals: 
 
In the alpaca pasture, a piece of woven wire from where an old enclosure used to be located was stuck in the ground and 
sticking up in an area where the alpacas could step on it. Woven wire sticking up could cause injury to the alpacas. 
Ensure to remove this wire and maintain the alpaca pasture in good repair to protect the animals from injury. 
***Correct by 6/9/2025. 
 
In the bison enclosure, a loop of wire is loose at the base of the fence near the area where the licensee feeds grain. There 
is also a gap below the fence in that area. The loop of wire could cause injury to the bison, and the gap below the fence 
could allow the public to contact the bison, resulting in injury to the animal or public. Ensure to maintain the bison's fence 
in good repair to protect and contain him. 
***Correct by 6/9/2025. 
 
The inspectors observed a small goat kid going under the primary enclosure fence where there was a gap and then going 
back in with the herd later. The primary enclosure fence does not contain all of the animals. If goats are not contained 
within their enclosure, they could get injured. Ensure that the fence is maintained in a manner that safely contains and 
protects the goats, including the small goat kids. 
***Correct by 6/17/2025. 
3.158(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Presence of wild rats observed during inspection indicates the licensee’s program for control of mammalian pests is not 
effective. During the inspection, inspectors observed at least two rats going into the silver pheasant's enclosure and 
eating grain near the pheasant. Rats can carry and spread diseases that could harm the animals. Ensure that a safe and 
effective program to control rodent pests such as rats is established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-
being of the birds and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas. 
***Correct by 6/20/2025.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative and the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
